Both India and Pakistan has been involved in skirmished along and beyond the LoC separating the disputed territory of Kashmir.  While the preponderant policy by both parties has always centered on this disputed region for close to 7 decades. Over the last year or so, both states actors in the dispute have decided that it will broaden its interaction with each other into domains of trade, water rights, non-state actors, and other significant issues.  While the trade between 2015 and 2016 has not improved (less than 2% in both cases), it continues to strive for cooperation in order to reduce its attention on the nuclear threats from both sides.  It should also be noted that despite the executive and legislative preferences in Pakistan, the military and its institutional form have veto and de facto controlled regarding matters of approaches and policies with regard to India.

The Indo-Pakistani War of 1965 was a culmination of skirmishes that took place between April 1965 and September 1965 between Pakistan and India. The conflict began following Pakistan's Operation Gibraltar, which was designed to infiltrate forces into Jammu and Kashmir to precipitate an insurgency against Indian rule. India retaliated by launching a full-scale military attack on West Pakistan.
